meanings.definition: Squeeze or twist (something) to force liquid out.
meanings.sent1: She had to wring the wet cloth to get all the water out.
meanings.sent2: I always wring out the sponge after washing dishes.
meanings.sent3: Trying to wring out a stone won't get you any water!
meanings.sent4: Her heartache seemed to wring out all the joy from her life.
meanings.sent5: The wrestler's grip was so tight, it felt like he could wring out a towel.

meanings.sent1: He had to wring every detail out of the witness during the interrogation.
meanings.sent2: She managed to wring a confession out of the suspect after hours of questioning.
meanings.sent3: Trying to wring out a secret from him was like pulling teeth.
meanings.sent4: The detective's sharp questions seemed to wring the truth out of the suspect.
meanings.sent5: The explorer had to wring the map coordinates out of the old book.

meanings.definition: Distort or twist out of shape.
meanings.sent1: The strong wind began to wring the tree branches out of shape.
meanings.sent2: The intense heat started to wring the plastic bottle out of shape.
meanings.sent3: The funhouse mirror seemed to wring his reflection out of shape.
meanings.sent4: The artist's abstract painting seemed to wring reality out of shape.
meanings.sent5: The magician's trick appeared to wring time and space out of shape.
